3.4. Halo Effect - Analytical MethodsÂ¶

3.4.1. Linear StabilityÂ¶

3.4.1.1. Single Beam Both Start with Electron FlavorÂ¶

We assume that both the forward and backward beams are starting from electron flavor.

\[\begin{split}\rho_F &= \frac{1}{2}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & \epsilon_F \\ \epsilon_F^* & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\ \rho_B &= \frac{1}{2}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & \epsilon_B \\ \epsilon_B^* & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

The linearized equation of motion is

\[\begin{split}i\partial_z \begin{pmatrix} \epsilon_F \\ \epsilon_B \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} R \mu + \eta & - R \mu \\ \mu & -(\mu+ \eta) \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \epsilon_F \\ \epsilon_B \end{pmatrix},\end{split}\]

where \(\eta\) is the hierarchy and all quantities are scaled by \(\omega_v\).

We can solve the eigenvalues of this problem. To obtain complex solutions, we require \(\Delta < 0\), which translates to

\[\mu_-< \mu <\mu_+,\]

where

\[\mu_\pm = \frac{ -2 (1+R) \eta \pm 8 \sqrt{ R } }{ (1-R)^2 }.\]

Fig. 3.13 Table of {\(\mu_{-}\), \(\mu_{+}\)}.

We plot out growth rate as a function of \(R\) and \(\mu\), which shows that such so called instabilities only exist for normal hierarchy.

Fig. 3.14 For normal hierarchy. Vacuum mixing angle is set to 0.

Fig. 3.15 For inverted hierarchy. Vacuum mixing angle is set to 0.

3.4.1.2. Single Beam Undetermined Back BeamÂ¶

The equation of motion is

\[\begin{split}i\partial_z \rho_F &= [ H_F, \rho_F ] \\ i\partial_z \rho_B &= [ H_B, \rho_B ] ,\end{split}\]

where

\[\begin{split}H_F &= R \mu \rho_B\\ H_B &= \mu \rho_F.\end{split}\]

Conventions

The angle contribution is \(1-\cos\theta=2\). We absorbe this factor into \(\mu\).

As for the initial states, we can assume some general forms

\[\begin{split}\rho_F &= \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \epsilon_F \\ \epsilon_F^* & -1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \rho_B &= \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} a & \epsilon_B \\ \epsilon_B^* & -a \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

The forward beam start from neutrino flavors. However, the state of the backward beam is to be determined. The exact state is not necessary since we are interested in linear stability.

We linearize the equation of motion by keeping only first order of the small off-diagonal elements.

\[\begin{split}i\partial_z \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \epsilon_F \\ \epsilon_F^* & -1 \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{ R \mu}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 2(a \epsilon_F -\epsilon_B) \\ c.c. & 0 \end{pmatrix} + \frac{R\mu}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 2(a\epsilon_F - b) \\ c.c. & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ - i\partial_z \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \epsilon_B \\ \epsilon_B^* & -1 \end{pmatrix} &= -\frac{\mu}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 2(a \epsilon_F -\epsilon_B) \\ c.c. & 0 \end{pmatrix} - \frac{\mu}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 2 (a\epsilon_F - b) \\ c.c. & 0 \end{pmatrix}\end{split}\]

The system of equations can be easily solved and we found that the exponentials are \(e^{i(2a R -1) \mu z}\). No exponent growth is possible.

eqnF = I D[epsF[z], z] == alpha mu (a epsF[z] - epsB[z]) + alpha mu (a epsF[z] - b)
eqnB = I D[epsB[z], z] == mu (a epsF[z] - epsB[z]) + mu (a epsF[z] - b)
DSolve[{eqnF,eqnB},{epsF,epsB},z]

The Two Beams have Synchronized Evolution

Notice that the two equations can be combined to

\[\partial_z \epsilon_F = \partial_z ( R \epsilon_B ).\]

This result indicates that the initial development of the forward and backward beams are synchronized.

Dealing with Inhomogenous Differential Equations

  1. The solution to inhomogenous systems is the general solution plus the particular solution. At least we can know that if the general solution contains exponential growth terms, the final solution should also contain exponential growth terms, if the particular solution doesnâ€™t cancel them.
  2. Floquet theory for periodic matrix systems might be useful.

3.4.2. Nonlocal Boundary Value ProblemÂ¶

Some References

  1. Springer Open has a curated list of NBVP. DENFC.
  2. To solve coupled systems with nonlocal boundary conditions: Goodrich, C. S. (2017). Pointwise conditions in discrete boundary value problems with nonlocal boundary conditions. Applied Mathematics Letters, 67, 7â€“15.
